instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3023: What is 820-3023? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.BKL_EN: What is BKL_EN? BKL_EN enables backlight. Anytime you see a signal ending with “_EN” , that means this signal being present/high enables what it is referring to. This signal says “BKL” before “_EN”. “BKL” sounds short for “BACKLIGHT”, so it is safe to assume this signal enables backlight when present. .
definitions.BKL_PWM: What is BKL_PWM? BKL_PWM sets the brightness of the screen. The system will send a PWM signal to BKL_PWM pin to set brightness. If this is low, backlight voltage will boost higher than PPBUS_G3H input, but not enough to make the screen light properly..
definitions.BLK_EN: What is BLK_EN? This is a typo of BKL_EN When you see BLK_EN, assume they meant to type BKL_EN.
definitions.Q9706: What is Q9706? Q9706 takes PPBUS_G3H's vltage and sends it through to the backlight circuit. If Q9706 is not allowing PPBUS_G3H through, you will get no voltage on the backlight circuit. Q9706 is a P channel MOSFET, meaning power will flow through it when the voltage on the gate is lower than on the source. Look at pin 3. R9788 takes the 12.6v that is on the source and places it right on pin 3. This will set Q9706 to "off", and not allow it to pass power, as the voltage on the source and the gate are identical..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3023</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> macbook air no backlight
threads.message: After cleaning this board no backlight, after some digging around decided to replace the <CHIP>U9701</CHIP> backlight driver. On plugging in the charger i get 50V on the backlight driver, but this drops down to ~20V after a split second. Without a screen plugged in i get 0 volts on the drive line. I've tried with a known good lcd. Am i just bad at soldering, or could there be something else going on?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3023</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> macbook air no backlight
threads.message: <SIGNAL>BKL_EN</SIGNAL> and PWM present? Connector not burned up inside?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3023</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> macbook air no backlight
threads.message:
It's taken a while for me to get back to this one, there's a lot of weird stuff happening with this machine.
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S0_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL> measures a steady 8.05 V without a screen, but as soon as i connect a screen it drops to about 4.8 V

i checked for presence of <SIGNAL>BLK_EN</SIGNAL>, it seems that the signal is coming through to <RESISTOR>R9731</RESISTOR>, but it stops there. Resistance on this measures in the high Mohms. I replaced the resistor, and also <CHIP>U9701</CHIP>, just in case. Resistances seem back to normal, but after i turn on the machine, with a screen connected, <SIGNAL>BKL_EN</SIGNAL> does not reach <CHIP>U9701</CHIP>. after disconnect it turns out the resistor is burned out again.

Also <SIGNAL>BKL_PWM</SIGNAL> measures 0.45 V at <CHIP>U9701</CHIP> with a screen connected.

It seems to me there could be trace damage under the <CHIP>U9701</CHIP> area that is causing this, but i'm a little at a loss since i've never seen this before. Is there something i can still try?

edit: how do i see if the connector is burned up?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3023</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> macbook air no backlight
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R9731</RESISTOR> is 200K. Now please tell me how much voltage you need to put through that to burn it up......yeah impossible indeed.
There should be no 8V present without an LCD connected as <TRANSISTOR>Q9706</TRANSISTOR> will not be told to open. I really have no clue what you are doing.....

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3023</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> macbook air no backlight
threads.message: Well neither do i, since i replaced the capacitor with a good one, measure the path, everything seems ok, but after trying it the resistor is no longer conducting. I know this is unlikely, but it does seem to be what is happening. I've seen the sticky about these backlight circuits, and i will redo the entire thing soonish and come back to this again to let you know if i'm making some stupid mistake with this.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3023</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> macbook air no backlight
threads.message: It is impossible to burn up a 200K resistor with the voltages present on the board. Resistor was killed by external forces, bad soldering etc.
